awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this research is to investigate the role of brain-produced cannabinoids in how the world is perceived at the level of the first stage of sensory processing in the brain. Sensory system processing is critical for an animal's ability to function within an environment. Humans and higher predator species are primarily visually oriented but most lower animal species utilize olfaction, the sense of smell, as a primary sensory modality. The ability of the olfactory system to detect a huge array of chemicals across wide concentration ranges is a formidable brain processing task. Processing of odor information in the first brain relay station, the main olfactory bulb, is a major contributor to this striking dynamic range. The experiments will increase the understanding of olfactory processing with potential impact on other sensory systems with similar circuit building mechanisms. Understanding the action of cannabinoids on sensory processing will shed light on how cannabinoids lead to altered sensory perception. Rather than purely higher order hallucinogenic action, the experiments will reveal how primary sensory modulation is influenced by cannabinoids and may lead to a better understanding of drug seeking behaviors. This research will provide an educational and outreach experience of exceptional quality for students at all levels with an emphasis on minority students at Howard University. The aim is to broaden the participation of students with minority background to expand the population of minority students as the science workforce of the future.

Marijuana (cannabis) is the most commonly abused illicit drug in the USA. Its bioactive ingredient, THC, activates cannabinoid receptors in the brain in the same manner as brain-produced endogenous cannabinoids (endocannabinoids). The endocannabinoid system is an important intrinsic neuromodulatory system during normal brain function and impacts sensory processing. The experiments take advantage of the highly laminar organization of the main olfactory bulb and a growing body of knowledge on how this system processes sensory information. This research will investigate the role of endocannabinoids in the olfactory system using whole-cell patch-clamp recordings, signal imaging and various mouse strains. Specifically, the research will explore how endocannabinoids regulate the activity of output neuron sensitivity and dynamic range in the main olfactory bulb. This will be followed by studying if environmental conditions such as a change in olfactory input engage endogenously produced cannabinoids. The researchers will exploit olfactory deprivation to identify the cellular, membrane, pharmacologic and network properties of endocannabinoid-modulated neural processing in the main olfactory bulb.

por.por_cntn:
Key to understanding brain functions is the relevance of neural modulation. Early sensory processing areas, such as the main olfactory bulb in the brain, provide an accessible window for investigating how neuromodulation regulates the functional states of neural networks and influences how we process sensory information. Olfaction is an attractive model system in this regard because of its relative simplicity and because it links primary olfactory sensory neurons in the nose to higher olfactory and associational networks. Sensory system processing of information is critical for an animal?s ability to function within an environment. While humans and apex predator species are primarily visually oriented, most animals utilize olfaction as their primary sensory modality. The ability of the olfactory system to detect a huge array of chemicals across wide concentration ranges is a formidable neural processing task. Neural processing within the main olfactory bulb is a major contributor to this striking system range.

Marijuana (cannabis) is the most abused illicit drug in the USA. Its bioactive ingredient, delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol, THC, activates cannabinoid receptors (CB1R) in the brain in the same manner as brain-produced endogenous cannabinoids (endocannabinoids). The endocannabinoid signaling system has been functionally implicated in many brain regions. Our understanding of the role of cannabinoid receptor type 1 in olfactory processing was limited. Therefore, the overarching goal of this research was to determine the physiological roles of endocannabinoids and cannabinoid receptors for neural signaling in olfactory bulb glomeruli, the first circuit in the olfactory system. Specifically, the cannabinoid-related circuitry of inputs to key olfactory bulb output neurons, mitral cells in the main olfactory bulb, was not fully understood.  Using anatomical and functional approaches we explored this question. Type 1 cannabinoid receptors were present in a population of nerve cells surrounding olfactory glomeruli, the inhibitory periglomerular cells, but not in mitral cells. We were able to detect endocannabinoids in the mouse main olfactory bulb and demonstrated the expression of cannabinoid receptors and other genes associated with cannabinoid signaling in the main olfactory bulb. Using electrophysiological techniques, we revealed that cannabinoid drugs indirectly activated mitral cells in the glomerular layer of the main olfactory bulb through direct cannabinoid receptor activation of periglomerular cells. This cannabinoid-mediated regulation of mitral cells potentially has effects on olfactory threshold and behavior.

These experiments explain how endocannabinoids modulate the activity of output neuron sensitivity and dynamic range to sensory signals. The results have increased our understanding of sensory processing of information, with impact on other sensory systems, since there are considerable similarities in neural circuits underlying all sensory systems.

As a broader impact, the research has provided an educational and outreach experience of exceptional quality at the undergraduate, graduate, and professional student level, with particular emphasis upon educational opportunities for African American students. We have broadened the participation of students with minority background at all levels to expand the population of minority students as the workforce of the future. The research has provided rigorous lab training with the opportunity to perform hands-on research and engaging back to the local community of Washington, DC where many of our minority students come from.
